title: Aunt Maria's Apple Pie
story: Legend has it that on a misty morning in 1897, Aunt Maria awoke from a dream so vivid she could still taste the perfect apple pie on her lips. The dream had shown her an orchard hidden in the mist-shrouded hills, where the apples had been kissed by both sun and moon. Determined to recreate this otherworldly pastry, Maria embarked on a journey across three counties, sampling apples from every orchard she encountered. One fateful evening, as autumn painted the countryside in gold and amber, she stumbled upon an old gnarled tree at the edge of a forgotten meadow. The tree, locals whispered, had been planted by a wandering monk who carried apple seeds blessed by a mysterious order. Maria gathered exactly seven apples—no more, no less—and hurried home through a sudden thunderstorm. As lightning illuminated her small kitchen, she began to bake, guided by the recipe that had appeared in her dream. The aroma that filled the house was so enticing that neighbors from miles around found themselves inexplicably drawn to her door. Since that night, Maria's apple pie has been served at every family gathering, the recipe closely guarded and passed down only to those deemed worthy of its secret. They say that whoever eats a slice of this mythical pie will be blessed with good fortune, and that the final bite should always be saved for midnight, when wishes made upon it are said to come true. The pie itself seemed to glow with an inner light, each slice revealing layers of perfectly caramelized apples arranged in a spiral pattern that resembled the golden ratio found in nature's most beautiful creations.
ingredients: 8 medium Granny Smith apples, peeled, cored, and sliced
2 tablespoons unsalted butter, cut into small pieces
1 egg beaten with 1 tablespoon water (for egg wash)
instructions: In a large bowl, combine flour, salt, and sugar.
Cut in the cold butter until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs with some pea-sized pieces.
Gradually add ice water, 1 tablespoon at a time, stirring with a fork until the dough holds together when pressed.
Divide the dough into two equal portions, shape into disks, wrap in plastic, and refrigerate for at least 1 hour.
In a large bowl, combine the sliced apples, sugar, flour, cinnamon, nutmeg, cloves, and lemon juice. Toss gently to coat.
Roll out one disk of dough on a floured surface to fit a 9-inch pie plate with about 1/2 inch overhang.
Transfer the dough to the pie plate and fill with the apple mixture. Dot with the 2 tablespoons of butter.
Roll out the second disk of dough and either place it over the filling for a double-crust pie or cut into strips for a lattice top.
Seal and crimp the edges. If using a full top crust, cut several slits to allow steam to escape.
Brush the top with egg wash and sprinkle with additional sugar.
Place the pie on a baking sheet and bake for 20 minutes at 425°F (220°C).
Reduce the oven temperature to 375°F (190°C) and continue baking for 30-40 minutes more, until the crust is golden brown and the filling is bubbling.
Let cool on a wire rack for at least 2 hours before serving to allow the filling to set.
